<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 329, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 907, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 907, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 507, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 907, 645]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 673, 608, 689]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 757, 705]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 771, 95]]<|/det|>
The sequence of positive numbers \(u_{1}\) , \(u_{2}\) , \(u_{3}\) , \(\ldots\) is such that \(u_{1}< 3\) and, for \(n\geqslant 1\) ,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 102, 565, 136]]<|/det|>
\[u_{n + 1} = \frac{4u_{n} + 9}{u_{n} + 4}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 157, 156, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 156, 920, 193]]<|/det|>
By considering \(3 - u_{n + 1}\), or otherwise, prove by mathematical induction that \(u_{n}< 3\) for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 171, 920, 190]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 411, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve is defined parametrically by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 100, 631, 121]]<|/det|>
\[x = t - \frac{1}{2}\sin 2t\quad \mathrm{and}\quad y = \sin^2 t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
The arc of the curve joining the point where \(t = 0\) to the point where \(t = \pi\) is rotated through one complete revolution about the \(x\)-axis. The area of the surface generated is denoted by \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 175, 156, 192]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 175, 243, 192]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 192, 576, 227]]<|/det|>
\[S = a\pi \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin^{3} t \mathrm{d}t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 230, 445, 249]]<|/det|>
where the constant \(a\) is to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 231, 920, 249]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 680, 92]]<|/det|>
Using the result \(\sin 3t = 3 \sin t - 4 \sin^3 t\), find the exact value of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) with \(\mathbf{e}\) as a corresponding eigenvector, and \(\mu\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{B}\) for which \(\mathbf{e}\) is also a corresponding eigenvector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\lambda + \mu\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}\) with \(\mathbf{e}\) as a corresponding eigenvector. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 153, 917, 173]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 196, 917, 215]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 238, 917, 256]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 280, 917, 298]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 322, 917, 339]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 427, 307, 445]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 445, 576, 497]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 448, 551]]<|/det|>
has \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\) as eigenvectors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 564, 153, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 564, 448, 581]]<|/det|>
Find the corresponding eigenvalues.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 564, 920, 581]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 598, 917, 616]]<|/det|>

<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 420, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{B}\) has eigenvalues 4, 5 and 1 with corresponding eigenvectors \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\), \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 4 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 477, 148, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 715, 496]]<|/det|>
Find a matrix \(\mathbf{P}\) and a diagonal matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \((\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B})^3 = \mathbf{P}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{P}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 685, 92]]<|/det|>
Justifying your answer, find the number of stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 512, 178, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 512, 759, 530]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of its point of intersection with the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 462, 92]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 98, 725, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\sin 8\theta = 8\sin \theta \cos \theta (1 - 10\sin^2\theta +24\sin^4\theta -16\sin^6\theta).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of the line of intersection of \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\), giving your answer in the form \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{a} + \lambda \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 588, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum distance of \(C\) from the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 612, 240, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 612, 240, 630]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 591, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the particular solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 100, 616, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}x}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}} +2\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} +10x = 37\sin 3t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 141, 475, 170]]<|/det|>
given that \(x = 3\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} = 0\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 147, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 524, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 201, 123]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 134, 796, 154]]<|/det|>
By considering \((2r + 1)^2 - (2r - 1)^2\), use the method of differences to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 163, 569, 198]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r = \textstyle \frac{1}{2} n(n + 1).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 189]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
By considering \((2r + 1)^{4} - (2r - 1)^{4}\), use the method of differences and the result given in part **(i)** to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 109, 918, 148]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r^{3} = \frac{1}{4} n^{2}(n + 1)^{2}. \quad [5]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 448, 304, 485]]<|/det|>
Let \(I_n = \int_{-1}^{0} x^n \frac{\mathrm{d}^n y}{\mathrm{d}x^n} \mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 494, 321, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label> Show that for \(n \geqslant 2\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 515, 917, 536]]<|/det|>
\[I_{n} = (-1)^{n + 1}A_{n - 1} - nI_{n - 1}. \quad [3]\]
